awd_titl_txt: Postdoctoral Fellowship: AAPF: Near-field Cosmology with 6D Stellar Streams
awd_abstract_narration:
Nora Shipp is awarded an NSF Astronomy and Astrophysics Fellowship to carry out a program of research and education at Carnegie Mellon University. Shipp will use observations and simulations of stellar streams orbiting the Milky Way to understand properties of dark matter and the physics of galaxy formation. For the educational component of this project, Shipp will establish training and volunteer opportunities in data science for social good for astronomers and physicists with data science expertise. 

This research project will establish robust predictions for populations of stellar streams around the Milky Way and beyond, using a variety of cosmological simulations and semi-analytic models. Shipp will then use large astronomical surveys, such as the Vera C. Rubin Observatory Legacy Survey of Space and Time (LSST) to test these predictions and to map the local distribution of dark matter, inform our models of small-scale galaxy formation, and measure the structure and assembly history of the Milky Way.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was to challenge and inform our understanding of galaxy evolution and dark matter physics through simulations and observations of tidally disrupting satellite galaxies around the Milky Way. As low-mass galaxies orbit the Milky Way, they are gradually torn apart by the gravitational forces of the host galaxy to form tidal debris structures, like extended stellar streams, and ultimately phase-mixed into a smooth stellar halo. The undisrupted satellite galaxies of the Milky Way have provided many of the strongest constraints to date on the properties of the dark matter particle and the intricacies of galaxy formation at the smallest scales. This project took advantage of cutting edge observational and computational resources to extend these impactful studies beyond the relatively small fraction of surviving satellites, and to incorporate systems at all stages of tidal disruption, across the accretion history of our Galaxy. 

In summary, the project built a framework for predicting the properties of disrupting satellite galaxies across dark matter and galaxy formation models, and for robustly comparing these predictions to observations in large astronomical surveys. The outcomes of this project will enable impactful studies on dark matter in the Local Universe with the upcoming data from the Rubin Observatory Legacy Survey of Space and Time (LSST).

In particular, the project produced two publications presenting the first detailed characterization of disrupting satellite galaxies around a large suite of simulated Milky Way-mass hosts. It also produced a tool for rapidly generating populations of disrupting satellite galaxies semi-analytically, which is available for public use on GitHub. These theoretical predictions will enable robust comparisons of observations to the predictions of dark matter and galaxy formation models, while accounting for key uncertainties including the effects of finite simulation resolution, galaxy modeling assumptions, and host galaxy properties. The project also produced tools for characterizing stellar streams in the upcoming data from LSST and for inferring the local properties of dark matter. The outcomes of this project will enable us in the coming years to take full advantage of the unprecedented LSST data and to robustly test detailed predictions of dark matter and galaxy formation in the Local Universe.

In addition, this project addressed the ethics of Artificial Intelligence (AI) in the new era of big data astronomy. The PI collaborated with local experts in ethical AI and Data Science for Social Good to provide educational and volunteer opportunities for astronomers. Additionally, the PI incorporated presentations and discussions on ethical AI into multiple conferences and collaboration meetings, reaching hundreds of members of the LSST community. These conversations on the ethical implications of AI use in the field of astronomy and throughout society as a whole have continued since the completion of the project, extending to other institutions and scientific collaborations.
